title: How to Make Grilled Sandwiches

steps.headline: Choose your bread based on your ingredients.
steps.description: One of the most integral parts of a grilled sandwich is the type of bread that you decide to use. All kinds of bread are perfectly fine for use, but some make more sense than others depending on what you will be putting inside the sandwich. If you’re planning on having very few ingredients then a basic thin bread will probably work best. If you’re going to be putting more ingredients in, then it may be worth exploring some heartier types of bread. Robust bread helps hold the ingredients together and also adds to the flavor of the sandwich.

steps.headline: Butter your bread on both sides.
steps.description: Ensure that the butter has been softened or is at least at room temperature. Trying to spread hard butter may result in you tearing the bread. Buttering the bread instead of the pan will prevent burning and ensure the bread cooks evenly. For some extra tang you can also use mayonnaise instead of butter. It will cook the same way and also add a little extra flavor to the sandwich.

steps.headline: Assemble your sandwich.
steps.description: Put all the ingredients together on your bread. If you are using cheese, make sure it is a cheese that will melt (eg. Swiss, American, mozzarella). Feel free to grate the cheese onto the bread to speed up the melting process. While assembling it’s important not to get too overzealous with how high you stack your sandwich. Eventually, you'll have to flip the sandwich and you don’t want it to fall apart.

steps.headline: Heat the non-stick pan to a medium heat.
steps.description: To ensure that the sandwich starts cooking the moment it touches the pan, preheat it before putting the sandwich in. This should be to a medium heat where the sandwich will be able to cook gently but also thoroughly. You can always turn the temperature down later if need be.

steps.headline: Place the sandwich into the skillet after 2-3 minutes of preheating.
steps.description: You should hear a nice sizzle when the bread hits the pan. This is a good sign and means the pan is at the right temperature for starting the bread at.

steps.headline: Turn the temperature down to a medium-low if you can.
steps.description: The higher the temperature, the faster the bread will cook. Therefore, once the sandwich is in and has made a nice initial sizzle, turning the temperature down by just a little bit will ensure that the bread doesn’t cook too fast for the fillings. Ideal temperatures for cooking vary depending on what is in your sandwich as some fillings cook faster than others. For example, mozzarella cooks very fast so when cooking a Caprese sandwich the temperature should be higher. This will mean the bread becomes golden at the same time that the mozzarella is melted.

steps.headline: Flip the sandwich after 2-3 minutes so it can cook on the other side.
steps.description: Doing this will get you a nice golden brown color on both sides of the sandwich. If your sandwich is packed with ingredients then hold a plate on top of your sandwich, flip the pan, then slide the sandwich back onto the pan.

steps.headline: Serve once golden brown on both sides.
steps.description: As soon as you have gotten the color you want on the bread and the ingredients inside have been cooked/melted, serve your sandwich. Be careful, it will be hot!

steps.headline: Pick a bread you like.
steps.description:
When using a panini press you can get away with using a basic thin bread with lots of ingredients as the sandwich is being pressed down and cooked from both sides. With that being said, feel free to explore and get creative with your bread choices. Some of these options might include:
Ciabatta
Multigrain
Sourdough
Rye

steps.headline: Butter both sides of both pieces of bread.
steps.description: This is integral to getting the nice golden color and buttery flavor for your bread. The outside of each piece will get toasted but buttering the inside allows more butter to melt into the bread and create a richer flavor.

steps.headline: Fill your sandwich with whatever ingredients you like.
steps.description: One of the advantages of using a panini press for your grilled sandwich is that it will have weight on top pushing downwards. This means you will have less trouble cooking with a full sandwich than with some other methods. If you do overload your sandwich, it’s possible that some ingredients get squeezed out the side. There isn’t anything wrong with this it’s just something to be aware of.

steps.headline: Cook for 3-5 minutes or until the bread is golden and the ingredients are well cooked.
steps.description: These times will vary depending on the thickness of the bread, the ingredients in your sandwich, and the panini press you are using, but this should be about right. The press should be on a medium heat if possible. You don’t need to fully close the lid on your panini press but you are welcome to do so if you would like a more compact sandwich. Pushing the panini press down when you have more ingredients will also mean the ingredients receive more of the heat from the top and bottom.

steps.headline: Take out and serve immediately.
steps.description: The sandwich will likely be quite hot so be careful, but your sandwich is now ready to enjoy! Cutting the sandwich in half will help cool the sandwich down a bit faster.

steps.headline: Make a Cuban for a more hearty meal.
steps.description:
This is a hugely popular option made popular by cafes in Florida catering to Cuban immigrant workers. The sandwich consists of the following ingredients:
Ham
Swiss cheese
Roast pork
Mustard
Pickles

steps.headline: Try an Italian Caprese style sandwich for a more summery option.
steps.description: This is an Italian inspired sandwich consisting of some of the most delicious Italian ingredients you can get. Mozzarella, pesto, tomato, and balsamic drizzle all combine to make a gooey and flavorsome delight. Mozzarella melts very fast so it’s a good idea to cook this sandwich on high so the bread gets golden as fast as the cheese melts. If you don't have any pesto on hand, basil will do just fine.

steps.headline: Explore a more exotic option with a Bombay grilled sandwich.
steps.description:
This is a sandwich originating in India and combines tasty ingredients for a more hearty sandwich. Ingredients include:
Boiled potato
Green chutney
Bell pepper
Tomato
Chaat masala
Onion

steps.headline: Stick with a classic grilled cheese option if you want to keep it simple.
steps.description: This one is a tried and true classic and gives you room to get as fancy or as simple as you like with the ingredients. All it requires is a lot of cheese and some good bread, and you’ll have an amazing tasty snack on your hands in no time. Use a cheese that melts well such as mozzarella, American, or cheddar.
